history.content:
Hi all,

Today in office hours we worked through an example FFT problem, 2.9a), a sort of prequel to the homework problem, 2.9b). I sort of glossed over the inverse FFT transform because I was having a bit of difficulty finding the best way to explain it so I wanted to post a follow-up here to clarify any lingering questions.

For the inverse FFT, we're doing the same process but taking the roots in reverse order. So we use that same relation $$A(\omega_n)=A_e(\omega_n^2)+\omega_nA_o(\omega_n^2)$$ where $$\omega_n=e^{i\frac{2\pi k}{n}}$$ except instead of $$k:0 \to n-1$$, we have the reverse order: $$k:n-1 \to 0$$. This corresponds to doing the four equations I wrote out from bottom to top when taking the inverse. After you get the result of this inverse FFT, you divide all the coefficients by n to complete the inverse. With that I hope you'll be able to see how to do the computation in conjunction with what was discussed in office hours today.
history.subject: Follow-up from today's office hours
